column2: Ellen McCormick choked a little as she answered him, promising to do what he asked.
column3: Ellen McCormick choked a little as she answered him, promising to do what he asked.

column2: He would always remember her as a sympathetic little thing, and half an hour later, after he had explained everything to Sandy, he wished her happiness when he took her hand in saying good-by. Her hand was trembling.
column3: He would always remember her as a sympathetic little thing, and half an hour later, after he had explained everything to Sandy, he wished her happiness when he took her hand in saying good by. Her hand was trembling.

column2: He wondered at it and said something to Sandy about the priceless value of a happiness such as his, as they went down to the beach.
column3: He wondered at it and said something to Sandy about the priceless value of a happiness such as his, as they went down to the beach.

column2: The velvety darkness of the sky was athrob with the heart-beat of stars, when the _Norden's_ shimmering trail led once more out to sea.
column3: The velvety darkness of the sky was athrob with the heart beat of stars, when the underscore Norden's underscore shimmering trail led once more out to sea.

column2: Alan looked up at them, and his mind groped strangely in the infinity that lay above him.
column3: Alan looked up at them, and his mind groped strangely in the infinity that lay above him.

column2: He had never measured it before.

column2: Life had been too full. But now it seemed so vast, and his range in the tundras so far away, that a great loneliness seized upon him as he turned his eyes to look back at the dimly white shore-line dissolving swiftly in the gloom that lay beneath the mountains.

column2: CHAPTER XI
column3: CHAPTER eleven

column2: That night, in Olaf's cabin, Alan put himself back on the old track again.
column3: That night, in Olaf's cabin, Alan put himself back on the old track again.

column2: He made no effort to minimize the tragedy that had come into his life, and he knew its effect upon him would never be wiped away, and that Mary Standish would always live in his thoughts, no matter what happened in the years to come.
column3: He made no effort to minimize the tragedy that had come into his life, and he knew its effect upon him would never be wiped away, and that Mary Standish would always live in his thoughts, no matter what happened in the years to come.

column2: But he was not the sort to let any part of himself wither up and die because of a blow that had darkened his mental visions of things.
column3: But he was not the sort to let any part of himself wither up and die because of a blow that had darkened his mental visions of things.

column2: His plans lay ahead of him, his old ambitions and his dreams of achievement.
column3: His plans lay ahead of him, his old ambitions and his dreams of achievement.

column2: They seemed pulseless and dead now, but he knew it was because his own fire had temporarily burned out.
column3: They seemed pulseless and dead now, but he knew it was because his own fire had temporarily burned out.

column2: And he realized the vital necessity of building it up again.
column3: And he realized the vital necessity of building it up again.

column2: So he first wrote a letter to Ellen McCormick, and in this placed a second letter--carefully sealed--which was not to be opened unless they found Mary Standish, and which contained something he had found impossible to put into words in Sandy's cabin.
column3: So he first wrote a letter to Ellen McCormick, and in this placed a second letter-carefully sealed-which was not to be opened unless they found Mary Standish, and which contained something he had found impossible to put into words in Sandy's cabin.

column2: It was trivial and embarrassing when spoken to others, but it meant a great deal to him.
column3: It was trivial and embarrassing when spoken to others, but it meant a great deal to him.

column2: Then he made the final arrangements for Olaf to carry him to Seward in the _Norden_, for Captain Rifle's ship was well on her way to Unalaska.
column3: Then he made the final arrangements for Olaf to carry him to Seward in the underscore Norden underscore, for Captain Rifle's ship was well on her way to Unalaska.

column2: Thought of Captain Rifle urged him to write another letter in which he told briefly the disappointing details of his search.
column3: Thought of Captain Rifle urged him to write another letter in which he told briefly the disappointing details of his search.

column2: He was rather surprised the next morning to find he had entirely forgotten Rossland.
column3: He was rather surprised the next morning to find he had entirely forgotten Rossland.

column2: He wanted to hear nothing he might have to say about Mary Standish.

column2: To associate them in any way, as he thought of her now, was little short of sacrilege.
column3: To associate them in any way, as he thought of her now, was little short of sacrilege.

column2: He was conscious of the change in himself, for it was rather an amazing upsetting of the original Alan Holt.
column3: He was conscious of the change in himself, for it was rather an amazing upsetting of the original Alan Holt.

column2: That person would have gone to Rossland with the deliberate and businesslike intention of sifting the matter to the bottom that he might disprove his own responsibility and set himself right in his own eyes. In self-defense he would have given Rossland an opportunity to break down with cold facts the disturbing something which his mind had unconsciously built up.

column2: But the new Alan revolted.

column2: He wanted to carry the thing away with him, he wanted it to live, and so it went with him, uncontaminated by any truths or lies which Rossland might have told him.
column3: He wanted to carry the thing away with him, he wanted it to live, and so it went with him, uncontaminated by any truths or lies which Rossland might have told him.

column2: They left Cordova early in the afternoon, and at sunset that evening camped on the tip of a wooded island a mile or two from the mainland. Olaf knew the island and had chosen it for reasons of his own.
column3: They left Cordova early in the afternoon, and at sunset that evening camped on the tip of a wooded island a mile or two from the mainland. Olaf knew the island and had chosen it for reasons of his own.

column2: It was primitive and alive with birds.
column3: It was primitive and alive with birds.

column2: Olaf loved the birds, and the cheer of their vesper song and bedtime twitter comforted Alan.
column3: Olaf loved the birds, and the cheer of their vesper song and bedtime twitter comforted Alan.

column2: He seized an ax, and for the first time in seven months his muscles responded to the swing of it.
column3: He seized an ax, and for the first time in seven months his muscles responded to the swing of it.

column2: And Ericksen, old as his years in the way of the north, whistled loudly and rumbled a bit of crude song through his beard as he lighted a fire, knowing the medicine of the big open was getting its hold on Alan again.
column3: And Ericksen, old as his years in the way of the north, whistled loudly and rumbled a bit of crude song through his beard as he lighted a fire, knowing the medicine of the big open was getting its hold on Alan again.

column2: To Alan it was like coming to the edge of home once more.
column3: To Alan it was like coming to the edge of home once more.

column2: It seemed an age, an infinity, since he had heard the sputtering of bacon in an open skillet and the bubbling of coffee over a bed of coals with the mysterious darkness of the timber gathering in about him. He loaded his pipe after his chopping, and sat watching Olaf as he mothered the half-baked bannock loaf.

column2: Olaf felt resting upon him something of the responsibility of a doctor, and after supper he sat with his back to a tree and talked of the old days as if they were yesterday and the day before, with tomorrow always the pot of gold at the end of the rainbow which he had pursued for thirty years.

column2: He was sixty just a week ago this evening, he said, and he was beginning to doubt if he would remain on the beach at Cordova much longer.

column2: Siberia was dragging him--that forbidden world of adventure and mystery and monumental opportunity which lay only a few miles across the strait from the Seward Peninsula.

column2: In his enthusiasm he forgot Alan's tragedy.

column2: He cursed Cossack law and the prohibitory measures to keep Americans out.

column2: More gold was over there than had ever been dreamed of in Alaska; even the mountains and rivers were unnamed; and he was going if he lived another year or two--going to find his fortune or his end in the Stanovoi Mountains and among the Chukchi tribes.

column2: He could not have told how long he slept that night.
column3: He could not have told how long he slept that night.

column2: Dreams came to him in his restless slumber, and always they awakened him, so that he was looking at the stars again and trying not to think.
column3: Dreams came to him in his restless slumber, and always they awakened him, so that he was looking at the stars again and trying not to think.

column2: In spite of the grief in his soul they were pleasant dreams, as though some gentle force were at work in him subconsciously to wipe away the shadows of tragedy. Mary Standish was with him again, between the mountains at Skagway; she was at his side in the heart of the tundras, the sun in her shining hair and eyes, and all about them the wonder of wild roses and purple iris and white seas of sedge-cotton and yellow-eyed daisies, and birds singing in the gladness of summer.
column3: In spite of the grief in his soul they were pleasant dreams, as though some gentle force were at work in him subconsciously to wipe away the shadows of tragedy. column2: He heard the birds.

column2: And he heard the girl's voice, answering them in her happiness and turning that happiness from the radiance of her eyes upon him.
column3: And he heard the girl's voice, answering them in her happiness and turning that happiness from the radiance of her eyes upon him.

column2: When he awoke, it was with a little cry, as if someone had stabbed him; and Olaf was building a fire, and dawn was breaking in rose-gleams over the mountains.
